variant.note: Rhyme and Reason An introduction to Minimalist Syntax,
variant.figure: Juan Uriagereka foreword by Massimo Piatelli-Palmarini
variant.bodyText: it is hard to Imagine a book that manages to explain both'the nuts and bolts of the theory of language and its deeper significance more lucidly or engagingly." = C.P. Otero, UCLA 694 pp., 216 illus. $70
variant.author: Frederick J. Newmeyer
variant.bodyText: An engaging and provocative inquiry...Newmeyer is well-informed, thoughtful and impeccably non- ideological. No doubt every linguist will find something in it to disagree with, but I think that everyone with a' serious interest in the history and , the future of syntactic theory will profit considerably from reading it." .— Peter W Culicover, The Ohio State University
variant.figure: Language, Speech, and Communication series 400 pp., 6 illus. $40 Language Creation and Language Change CreolizatIon, Dlachrony, and Development edited by Michel DeGraff
variant.figureCaption: Explores relationships among the three processes by which languages, in particular grammars, change and hence are created anew: when one language is absorbed into another, over long periods of time and usage, and when children learn language.
variant.figure: Learning, Development, and Conceptual Change series • 586 pp., 4 illus. $65 On the Pragmatics of Communication Jargen Habermas edited by Maeve Cooke
variant.bodyText: An anthology of Habermas' major statements of his program in formal pragmatics, which underpins his theory of communicative action.
variant.footnote: Studies in Contemporary German Social Thought 416 pp. $35
variant.author: Kenneth N. Stevens
variant.bodyText: "Whenever anybody wants to know why the acoustic structure of a particular sound is as it is. this is the book to which they will turn. There is absolutely no other book with anything like this depth of coverage.' — Peter Ladefoged, UCLA
variant.footnote: Current Studies in Linguistics 30 672 pp., 700 illus. $60
variant.note: edited by Dana McDaniel, Cecile McKee, and Helen Smith Cairns
variant.bodyText: This book is designed in part as a handbook to assist students and researchers in the choice and use of methods for investigating children's grammar. Language, Speech, and Communication series A Bradford Book 408 pp., 7 illus. $20 paper The Dependencies of Objects

Investigates the nature, properties, and consequences of the grammati- cal constraints that yield overt marking of objects in a variety of languages. Linguistic Inquiry Monograph 34 216 pp. $20 paper Three Investigations of Extraction

Focuses on three problems in the theory of syntax, unified by their connection to "extraction," the displacement of an element via grammatical processes from the position where it would logically seem to belong.
variant.footnote: Current Studies In Linguistics 29 232 pp. $32.50 To order call 800- 358-0343 (US & Canada) or (617) 625- 8569. Prices higher outside U.S. and subject to change without notice. http://mitpress.mitedu
variant.subsectionHeader: An Experience-Based Theory of Language Data Oriented Parsing Rens Bod
variant.bodyText: During the past few years, a new approach to language processing has started to emerge, which has become known under the name of Data Ori- ented Parsing (DOP). This approach embodies the assumption that human language perception and production works with representations of concrete past language experiences, rather than with abstract grammar rules.
variant.subsectionHeader: Presupposition and Anaphora Emiel Jacques Krahmer
variant.bodyText: In this book, two related phenomena are studied: presupposition and ana- phora. Dynamic semantics is by now widely accepted as a first-rate founda- tion for such an exercise and it forms the backbone of most of the work in this book. A recurring additional theme of the present book is the usefulness of techniques from partial logic in the treatment of both phenomena.
variant.subsectionHeader: Abstract Specification of Grammar Algebraic Specification Language: A Case Study Michael Newton
variant.bodyText: This book explores the use of an alge- braic (software) specification language (ASL) in the description and modeling of natural language grammar. An abstract description of constituency is given, independent of concrete styles of grammar, which demonstrates the need for an intensional domain.
variant.author: John Nerbonne, Editor
variant.figureCaption: This book explores the increasing use of databases in linguistics. The enormous potential in linguistic data—billions of utterances and messages daily—has been difficult to exploit. Included in this volume are reports on database activities in phonetics, phonology, lexicography and syntax, comparative grammar, second-language acquisition, linguistic fieldwork and language pathology.
variant.figure: 1-57586-093-7 Hardback $64.95 1-57586-092-9 Paperback $24.95 A Descriptive Approach to Language-Theoretic Complexity
variant.bodyText: This book presents a natural and quite general means of expressing constraints on the structure of trees and shows that the languages that can be specified by systems of such constraints are exactly those computable by a particular standard class of abstract machines.
variant.subsectionHeader: Learnable Classes of Categorial Grammars Makoto Kanazawa
variant.bodyText: "The book does an excellent job of sum- marizing previous work and preparing the reader for the main results. The text is clean, the presentation clear and rigor- ous, and the comprehensive list of refer- ences will be helpful to anyone wishing to pursue some of the interesting open questions raised in this monograph."
This book investigates learnability of various classes of classical categorical grammars within the Gold paradigm of identification in the limit from positive data.
variant.figure: 1-57586-097-X Hardback $59.95 1-57586-096-1 Paperback $22.95 FROM CAMBRIDGE CAMB RID GE 40 West 20th Street, New York, NY 10011-4211 Call toll-free 800-872-7423. Web site: http://www.cup.org UNIVERSITY PRESS MasterCardNISA accepted. Prices subject to change. Dynamic Conceptual Semantics A Data-oriented Theory of Concept Formation and Understanding Renate Bartsch
variant.bodyText: Presented in this book is a theory of concept formation and understanding that does not make use of a notion of an innate mental language as a means of concept representation. Instead, experiental concepts are treated seman- tically as stabilizing structuring of growing sets of data, which are sets of experienced satisfaction situations for expressions, and theoretical concepts are based on coherent sets of general sentences held true.
variant.figure: 1-57586-125-9 Hardback $64.95 1-57586-124-0 Paperback $24.95 Computing Natural Language Context, Structure, and Processes Atocha Aliseda-Liera, Rob Van Glabbeek, and Dag Westerstahl, Editors
variant.bodyText: This book pursues the recent upsurge of research in the interface of logic, language and computation, with applications to artificial intelligence and machine learning. It contains a variety of contributions to the logical and computational analysis of natural language. A wide range of logical and computational tools are employed and applied to such varied areas as context- dependency, linguistic discourse, and formal grammar.
variant.figure: What Comes First in Dynamic Semantics A Critical Review of Linguistic Theories of Presupposition and a Dynamic Alternative David Beaver Inspired by Frege, who's work in Linguistic Presupposition initiated
variant.bodyText: the modern study, Beaver shares with the reader the most comprehensive overview and critical discussion of this burgeoning field published to date. The central plank of the theory of meaning is a formal account cf the change in information effected by use of language on hearers or readers. At the same time it provides a new impulse and motivation to Dynamic Semantics itself.
variant.figure: 1-57586-121-6 Hardback $64.95 1-57586-120-8 Paperback $24.95 Discourse and Cognition Bridging the Gap
variant.figureCaption: Jean-Pierre Koenig, Editor This volume brings together research from both "cognitive" and "functional" approaches to linguistics. The collec- tion includes work from cognitive science disciplines whose concerns overlap with linguistics, such as arti- ficial intelligence, neurolinguistics and psychology. Despite their diver- sity, the papers in this volume are all inspired by the same fundamental question: To what extent is the structure of languages affected by human cognitive structures and language use?
variant.figure: 1-57586-101-1 Hardback $59.95 1-57586-115-1 Hardback $69.95 1-57586-100-3 Paperback $22.95 1-57586-114-3 Paperback $27.95 Available in bookstores or from "The leading periodical dealing with neuroscience." Nature 1998 Rates

variant.author: Terrence Sejnowski, Editor
variant.subsectionHeader: The Salk Institute and University of California at San Diego
variant.bodyText: Published 8 times per year by The MIT Press in January/February/April/May/July/August/October/November Now in its tenth year, Neural Computation has established itself as the leading journal for a growing community of scientists interested in exploring the computational principles that make brains tick. Carefully reviewed by a distinguished editorial board, Neural Computation publishes short communications, long artides and timely reviews on the interplay between experimental data, computational models, and theoretical analysis at all levels of organization in the brain, from the molecular to the systems levels.
variant.table: Select Articles from Volume 10 Memory Maintenance via Neuronal Regulation David Horn, Nir Levy and Eytan Ruppin Ordering of Self-Organizing Maps in Multi-Dimensional Cases Guang-Bin Huang, Haroon A. Babri, and Hua-Tian Li Predicting the Distribution of Synaptic Strengths in a Self-Organizing, Sequence Prediction Model Asohan Amarasingham, and William B. Levy State Dependent Weights for Neural Associative Memories Ravi Kothari, Rohit Lotiikar, and Marc Cathay
variant.subsubsectionHeader: Neural Computation is available on BioMedNet, The World Wide Club
variant.bodyText: for the Biological and Medical Community. Please visit http://biomednacom for details!
variant.figure: http://mitpress.mitedu " . Artificial Life is a very cool. . . scholarly journal." —Wired Artificial
variant.figureCaption: " . a remarkable profusion of topics . . . For aficionados, the journal is a must. Theoretical biologists, empirical mathematicians. .. will also do well to follow Artificial Life . ." —Nature Artificial Life is the first unifying forum for the dissemination of scientific research in the new field of artificial life. Relevant topics span the hierarchy of biological organization, including studies of the origin of life, self-assembly, growth and develop- ment, evolutionary and ecological dynamics, animal and robot behavior, social organization, and cultural evolution. " ... The [editors] account for most of the influential researchers in this field. All involved deserve credit for attempting the difficult task of producing a truly interdisciplinary journal.

Artificial Life Online is a VVVVVV- and ftp- accessible Internet service that provides a variety of information to the artificial life research community: artificial-life- related software, papers, FAQs, discussion forums; and mailing lists.

variant.sectionHeader: 1998 MEMBERSHIP, CHANGE OF ADDRESS AND EMAIL, AND ORDER FORM MEMBERSHIP
variant.bodyText: Membership in the Association for Computational Linguistics is for the calendar year, regardless of when dues are paid. Membership includes a full year of the ACL journal, Computational Linguistics, reduced registration at most ACL-sponsored conferences, and discounts on ACL-sponsored publications. Payments for membership dues, fund donations, back issues, and proceedings may be made in Europe or the USA. Follow the instructions under the PAYMENT heading carefully. Provide all personal information, even if you have previously done so. to be sure the ACL membership database is up-to-date. Write legibly. Please! Do not fill in your name/address unless the mailing label below is incorrect.
(first) (last/family)
(if not in address above)

Please IMMEDIATELY notify the ACL Office of address and email changes. Journal copies returned due to bad addresses will not be remailed until a $5.00 postage/handling fee is remitted. EMAIL (if available) IS USED TO DISTRIBUTE_meeting. membership, and other announcements.

IMPORTANT NOTE: Renewals must be received no later than 1 April 1998 to avoid late payment fee assessment. Membership categories include Regular Members and the following: Couples with the same mailing address may be Joint Members; they will receive only one set of publications, but each will be eligible for all other member benefits. Students taking a full-time program of courses and not earning a regular income may become Student Members WITH COPY OF CURRENT STUDENT ID, Students who are not Student Members because of their income can still participate in student acti.vites as Student-Employed. Also available are Retired and Unemployed memberships. PLEASE
variant.table: CIRCLE / HIGHLIGHT TYPE OF MEMBERSHIP BELOW THAT YOU DESIRE. Late payment fee does not apply to new memberships. Regular($60) Joint($70) Student($30) Student-Employed($60) Retired($30) Unemployed($30) MEMBERSHIP DUES $ 1st Class or Air ($10 US, Canada, Mexico; $25 elsewhere) OPTIONAL JOURNAL MAILING $ RENEWALS received after 1 April 1998 pay $20 additional postage/handling fee LATE PAYMENT FEE $ INTERNATIONAL FUND: Allows ACL memberships and publications lobe available to colleagues who have difficulty in using their national currencies for international transactions or for whom membership would otherwise be impossible. Contributions may be tax deductible; check local regulations. Receipts are available upon request. INTERNATIONAL FUND $ THE DON AND BETTY WALKER INTERNATIONAL STUDENT FUND: This fund was set up to honor Don and Betty Walker. It supports select student travel to ACL meetings. Contributions may be tax deductible, and companies may provide matching funds; check local regulations. Receipts are available upon request. Make checks payable to "THE WALKER FUND". Visa and Mastercard payments are also accepted. Payment may be made by sending this form (or all pertinent details) and credit card information in email to acl@bellcore.com (prior to February 1,1998) or to acl@aclweb.org (after February 1, 1998). The following payment choices are available:

variant.bodyText: (December 1997, Kathleen McKeown, ACL Secretary/Treasurer) (list in PAYMENT SECTION)

Manuscripts for Computational Linguistics should be submitted on letter-size paper (8.5 by 11 inches, or A4), double-spaced and single-sided throughout, including footnotes and refer- ences. The paper should begin with an informative abstract of approximately 150-250 words. Manuscripts must be written in English. Contact the editor regarding the possibility of electronic submission.
variant.subsectionHeader: Submissions may be made in any of the following categories: ,
variant.bodyText: Papers: This category includes contributions that report significant new research results in com- putational linguistics or that provide critical reviews of the literature on a particular topic. The length of a paper depends on its content, but it is suggested that manuscripts be limited to forty double-spaced, pages. That is the equivalent of thirty journal pages. Each paper is fully refereed by three or four experts in the field. Manuscripts may also be submitted electronically; consult http:/ /www.cs.columbia.edu/—radev/acl/subrnit.txt for instructions and pointers to the LATEX style files. The submission of ah article to CL for refereeing means that the author certifies the manuscript is not Copyrighted; nor has it been published or submitted for publica- tion to another refereed journal. If any version of the paper has appeared, or will appear, in a non-refereed publication, the details of such publication must be made known to the Editor at the time of submission. The final version of a paper tentatively accepted for publication must be accompanied by a Copyright Transfer Agreement signed by all of the authors or, in the case of a "work for hire," by the employer. This written transfer is necessary under the 1978 U.S. Copyright law. Letters to the Editor: This category includes statements of opinion on- issues relevant to the readership. The Editor and the editorial board will evaluate the appropriateness of these con- tributions for inclusion. Five copies of papers or three copies of letters should be sent to:
variant.table: Julia Hirschberg, CL Editor AT&T Labs-Research 180 Park Avenue, A237 Florham Park, NJ 07932-0971 (+1 973) 360-8330; acl@research.att.com Squibs and Discussions: This category includes short articles reporting technical results, dis- cussions of results, algorithms, or new computational linguistic data or tools of interest to the journal readership. Submission format is the same as for regular papers, but the length should in no case exceed eight journal pages. Electronic submissions (LATEX source, postscript or plain text) are welcome and should be submitted to: Pierre Isabelle, CL Squibs and Discussions Editor RALI, DIRO Universite de Montreal C. P. 6128, Succ. Centre-ville Montreal, Quebec, CANADA H3C 3J7 (+1 514) 343-6161; isabelle@iro.umoritreal.ca Book Section: Anyone interested in reviewing a book, or in suggesting a book for review, should contact the Book Review Editor; publishers may also submit copies of books for review directly to: Graeme Hirst, CL Book Review Editor University of Toronto Department -of Computer Science Toronto, CANADA M5S 3G4 (+1 416) 978-8747; gh@cs.toronto.edu
variant.bodyText: Founded in 1962, the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL) is the primary scientific and professional society for natural language processing research and applications. A European chapter was established in 1982. Besides publishing Computational Linguistics, the ACL holds international meetings (annually in North America, biennially in Europe) where the state-of-the-art in natural language processing research and development is presented. Recently, special interest groups on the Mathematics of Language, the Lexicon, Parsing, Generation, Computational Phonology, Multimedia Language Processing, and Very Large Corpora have been formed; others are likely to be added.
